dt: {bc}to spring back to or as if to a starting point {bc}{sx|rebound||}

pt: {sc}recoil{/sc} {sc}shrink{/sc} {sc}flinch{/sc} {sc}wince{/sc} {sc}blench{/sc} {sc}quail{/sc} mean to draw back in fear or distaste. {sc}recoil{/sc} implies a start or movement away through shock, fear, or disgust.
{sc}shrink{/sc} suggests an instinctive recoil through sensitiveness, scrupulousness, or cowardice.
{sc}flinch{/sc} implies a failure to endure pain or face something dangerous or frightening with resolution.
{sc}wince{/sc} suggests a slight involuntary physical reaction (such as a start or recoiling).
{sc}quail{/sc} suggests shrinking and cowering in fear.

et: Middle English {it}reculen, recoilen{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}reculer, recuiler{/it}, from {it}re-{/it} + {it}cul{/it} backside {ma}{mat|culet|}{/ma}
shortdef: to shrink back physically or emotionally
to spring back to or as if to a starting point : rebound

dt: {bc}the kickback of a gun upon firing

dt.t: the {wi}recoil{/wi} from the rigors of Calvinism

shortdef: the act or action of recoiling; especially : the kickback of a gun upon firing

dt: {bc}utilizing the movement of parts in recoil to operate the action

shortdef: utilizing the movement of parts in recoil to operate the action
